title: Using Async generators in the startup event
body:
Hi,

I am running into a strange issue. I am using Aikafka to run a consumer which I start in the startup event. It looks like this:
```
async def consume():
    consumer = AIOKafkaConsumer(
        'topic',
        loop=asynio.get_running_loop(),
        client_id="experiment_consumer",
        bootstrap_servers=f"server:port",
        enable_auto_commit=False,
    )
    await consumer.start()
    async for msg in consumer:
        print("consumed: ", msg.topic, msg.partition, msg.offset,
                msg.key, msg.value, msg.timestamp)

@app.on_event('startup')
async def app_startup():
    asyncio.create_task(consume())
```
I would expect messages to be printed when published to a topic but nothing gets printed out. As soon as I restart the FastAPI process then the points are being printed. 
I think this may have to do with the async generator used by AIOKafka. Any ideas on what might be going on here?
author: m4nuC

comments.body:
you can try:

```python
@app.on_event('startup')
async def app_startup():
    await consume()
```
@Dustyposa thanks for the suggestion, I did try this, it results in the application startup hanging as the  `consume` call never terminates(it's an async generator)

got it.
You need run it in another process.
Why you want to run it with app in same processï¼Ÿ
it should be possible to work on a single thread, it's what asyncio is for after all. So I'd like to keep multithreading as a last resort

@m4nuC hello! Are you sure that all is fine with your AIOKafkaConsumer setup?
With this async gen emulation I've achieved constant printing:
```
async def async_gen():
    i = 0
    while True:
        await asyncio.sleep(0.5)
        yield i
        i += 1

async def consume():
    async for msg in async_gen():
        print(f"i: {msg}")


app = FastAPI()


@app.on_event('startup')
async def app_startup():
    asyncio.create_task(consume())
```

@insomnes Thanks for the snippet. I have tried that code have exactly the same symptoms, that is, no printing then I get everything all at once when I restart the FastAPI process. What is even stranger is that If I use the standard python logging library then the printing is indeed constant. Wonder if this could have something to do with gunicorn and possibility multiple fastAPI processes running. Looking into that now.


In dev environment (have not yet tried prod), this is how I start the server:
`exec uvicorn --reload --reload-dir /app --host $HOST --port $PORT --log-level $LOG_LEVEL "$APP_MODULE"`

Could anyone spot something odd ?

@insomnes It turned out to be the `print` command that was buffering output once inside an async generator. So flushing with `sys.out.flush` on each iteration solve my issue. That said I am not sure why this behavior happens only inside the generator

Thanks for the help here @Dustyposa and @insomnes  ! ğŸ‘  ğŸ™‡ 

Thanks for reporting back and closing the issue @m4nuC  ğŸ‘

> Sorry for the long delay! ğŸ™ˆ  I wanted to personally address each issue/PR and they piled up through time, but now I'm checking each one in order.

title: the middleware is so slow
body:
I using the test case which is a helloworld example with 6 empty middleware(doing nothing).
And it significant slowdown. Loss 70% performance vice not using middleware.
And i notice the code using in TechEmpower is without middleware.
Deep in the code I found out the middleware runing is using too many coroutine(create task).
I think there should be some performance fixed for the middleware in fastapi.
author: wesdu

comments.body: Can you give a demonstration of your issue?

```
from fastapi import FastAPI, Request
import uvicorn

app = FastAPI(debug=False)


@app.middleware("http")
async def a(request: Request, call_next):
    response = await call_next(request)
    return response

@app.middleware("http")
async def b(request: Request, call_next):
    response = await call_next(request)
    return response

@app.middleware("http")
async def c(request: Request, call_next):
    response = await call_next(request)
    return response

@app.middleware("http")
async def d(request: Request, call_next):
    response = await call_next(request)
    return response


@app.get("/")
async def run():
    return {"message": "hello"}


if __name__ == '__main__':
    uvicorn.run('test:app', host='0.0.0.0', port=8888, reload=True, debug=False)
```
when using the 4 level middleware 
I got 
`Requests per second:    1753.81 [#/sec] (mean)`
 using `ab -c 100 -n 10000`

otherwise, remove the empty middleware 
```
from fastapi import FastAPI, Request
import uvicorn

app = FastAPI(debug=False)

@app.get("/")
async def run():
    return {"message": "hello"}


if __name__ == '__main__':
    uvicorn.run('test:app', host='0.0.0.0', port=8888, reload=True, debug=False)
```
I got 
`Requests per second:    3450.91 [#/sec] (mean)`
The middleware has a very strong impact on the performance, I don't think it should be.

`BaseHTTPMiddleware` should be avoided (but not related to this issue).

import fastapi

title: Improve response time latency
body:
Hi there, 
I am recently using fast api for machine learning prediction.
However, the model is loaded once when the server is began, and I communicate with the database only twice before and after prediction, it seems that there is a bottleneck in my code. I tried to check the robustness of my server with sending requests by threads. When there is less than 10 request every thing is fine and the max response time is acceptable. But when I increase the number of thread to about 100, the server response time increase exponentially and it might get even 200 seconds for client  to receive the response. 
CAn wany body have any Idea?
I do use asysnc and await keywords in both when accessing to the database and the prediction function.
The sequential response time is less than 1 second.
How can I improve the performance of my server when it is supposed to process a huge number of requests.
author: marziehoghbaie

comments.body: What do you mean by improve response time latency?
@ycd I provided more details about my problem

The response time is quite annoying, cause every thing works fine, my friend has implemented the same project in flask, and its delay is less than 10 second under the same circumstances, 
And it make me to think why FastAPI does not work?
it supposed to be faster

You are missing the main point of asynchronous IO.

> it supposed to be faster

You are doing a heavy computation that takes more than >1 sec. If that computation is not a coroutine(It's 99% not.) asyncio does not do any context switching.

This means it is going to block your event loop.

You should use `def` instead of `async def` for that endpoint.  By default, FastAPI will run handle your request  `run_in_threadpool` when your endpoint is not a coroutine. It is better for endpoints that does heavy computation.

Can you try changing that endpoint to `def` instead of `async def`?

                  user: Optional[User] = Depends(fastapi_users_.get_current_user)):
         pass

Besides, If one user sends many requests at once they might need to update the DB in an async manner in a update function and to avoid resource starvation I do something like 
```
    try:
        session.add(db_item)
        session.commit()
        session.refresh(db_item)
    except:
        session.rollback()
    finally:
        session.close()
```

title: FastAPI on a VPS - what will be the bottleneck?
body:
I will host my FastAPI backend on a VPS server with 4 vCPU Cores, 8GB RAM, SSD for storage and 300MBit Upload bandwith.
An endpoint usually triggers:
- two SELECT (lets say 50% of the rquests)
- one SELECT and one ADD ROW ( 25% of the requests)
- one SELECT and one UPDATE ROW (25% of the requests)
These are async calls to a Postgres database (with the package "databases").

With this environment, what will be the bottleneck and what should be upgraded to increase the number of requests/second? CPU cores, RAM or the bandwith?
author: Koliham

comments.body: Are you currently seeing performance issues?

> 
> 
> Are you currently seeing performance issues?

It is more fore long-term planning to make the appication scalable, that I know where to invest.. I have two VPS providers. One is offering more vCPU cores, the other one is offering more bandwith,

This question really depends on what you are trying to achieve.

 > `two SELECT`  

It is just one select? Usually, aggregation and ordering cause bottlenecks since they are CPU intensive operations. This question also depends on what is your expectation from the database. How many rows do you expect?
"Premature optimization is the root of all evil."

I am using FastApi to build simple api, there are two tables, with users and account type.
When creating user there is also created record in account type table. It is there, I checked it.
When I am trying to display user information it shows me this error:
```
pydantic.error_wrappers.ValidationError: 2 validation errors for User
response -> account -> active
  field required (type=value_error.missing)
response -> account -> id
  field required (type=value_error.missing)

Here is my code:

main.py
```
@app.post("/api/register/", response_model=schemas.User)
def create_user(user: schemas.UserCreate, db: Session = Depends(get_db)):
    db_user = crud.get_user_by_email(db, email=user.email)
    if db_user:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="Email already exists.")
    if user.password != user.password_repeat:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="Passwords have to be the same.")
    
    user.password = get_password_hash(user.password)
    return crud.create_user(db=db, user=user)

@app.get("/api/users/{user_id}", response_model=schemas.User)
def get_user_by_id(user_id: int, db: Session = Depends(get_db)):  
    db_user = crud.get_user_by_id(db=db, user_id=user_id)
    if db_user is None:

    return db_user
```

schemas.py

# Account

    active: bool

models.py

lass User(Base):

def create_user(db: Session, user: schemas.UserCreate):

As it is not a list but single record, is there a way to display it as a dict?

```
{
  "name": "string",
  "email": "user@example.com",
  "id": 1,
  "uuid": "920b80eec9384f9fa716568c5bba64a4",
  "is_active": false,
  "account": [
    {
      "account_type": "Free",
      "expire_date": null,
      "active": true,
      "option": null
    }
  ]
}
```

Edit 2:
I solved it by adding  uselist=False to relationship declaration in User class
```
account = relationship("Account", back_populates="user", uselist=False)
```
Thank you

title: JSON encoding of nested Pydantic objects does not use custom encoders of nested objects
body:
### Example

Must install `qcelemental` first! Pardon that I'm not able to take the core issues and create a simpler example without this external package; however, this demonstrates the core problem well.

```sh
pip install qcelemental
```

```Python
from pydantic import BaseModel
from fastapi.encoders import jsonable_encoder
from qcelemental.models import Molecule
from numpy import array, ndarray


molecule_data = {
    "schema_name": "qcschema_molecule",
    "schema_version": 2,
    "validated": True,
    "symbols": array(["O", "H", "H"], dtype="<U1"),
    "geometry": array(
        [
            [0.0, 0.0, 0.0],
            [0.52421003, 1.68733646, 0.48074633],
            [1.14668581, -0.45032174, -1.35474466],
        ]
    ),
    "name": "IUPAC oxidane",
    "molecular_charge": 0.0,
    "molecular_multiplicity": 1,
    "fix_com": False,
    "fix_orientation": False,
    "provenance": {
        "creator": "QCElemental",
        "version": "v0.17.0",
        "routine": "qcelemental.molparse.from_string",
    },
}


class NestedMolecule(BaseModel):
    molecule: Molecule


class NestedMoleculeRepeatedEncoders(NestedMolecule):
    class Config:
        json_encoders = {ndarray: lambda x: x.tolist()}


molecule = Molecule.parse_obj(molecule_data)
nested_molecule_repeat_encoders = NestedMoleculeRepeatedEncoders(molecule=molecule)
nested_molecule = NestedMolecule(molecule=molecule)

# Works great! Fastapi picks up the custom encoders/serialization methods on Molecule and can encode the object and ultimately return a JSONResponse (if this were the response_model on a path)
jsonable_encoder(molecule)

# Works! But why do I have to duplicate these encoders that already exist on the Molecule object??
jsonable_encoder(nested_molecule_repeat_encoders)

# Fails to properly encode numpy.ndarray field at nested_molecule.molecule.geometry. A JSONResponse with response_model=NestedMolecule would fail.
jsonable_encoder(nested_molecule)
```

### Description
Fastapi appears to correctly utilize the custom json encoding/serialization methods found on `Molecule`. Great! However, if I nest a `Molecule` inside another Pydantic model, fastapi does not correctly pick up these serialization customizations. In order to use a `NestedMolecule` I have to add custom `json_encoders` to the `Config` class, as seen on `NestedMoleculeRepeatedEncoders`. But why do I have to do this? Seems fastapi should pick up the custom encoders on nested Pydantic objects just like it does on the original `Molecule` object. I believe this is a bug.

One way to help see what's going on here is to add `print(type(obj), obj)` on line 37 of `fastapi.encoders` to see how the `jsonable_encoder` function is correctly handing the first two cases and fails the third case.

### Environment

* OS: MacOS:
* FastAPI Version 0.62.0:
* Python version: 3.9.0
author: coltonbh

title: Body for RedirectResponse
body:
Good day.

I found some conflict (as I see it) between RedirectResponse class and openapi schema.

```Python
class RedirectResponse(Response):
    def __init__(
        self,
        url: typing.Union[str, URL],
        status_code: int = 307,
        headers: dict = None,
        background: BackgroundTask = None,
    ) -> None:
        super().__init__(
            content=b"", status_code=status_code, headers=headers, background=background
        )
        self.headers["location"] = quote_plus(str(url), safe=":/%#?&=@[]!$&'()*+,;")
```

We can't define a content. But only 304 status code (of the redirect codes) really can't have a body. 

This fact and `STATUS_CODES_WITH_NO_BODY = {..., 304}` makes a trouble with openapi schema validation. 

May be, we should allow set a content with check for the 304 status_code (and nullify content if it is)?
author: mrkovalchuk

comments.body:
I believe 204 is fine since it is named ` No Content`, also RFC states it clearly by saying it must not include a message-body.

> The 204 response MUST NOT include a message-body, and thus is always terminated by the first empty line after the header fields.

> I believe 204 is fine since it is named ` No Content`, also RFC states it clearly by saying it must not include a message-body.
> 
> > The 204 response MUST NOT include a message-body, and thus is always terminated by the first empty line after the header fields.

It's issue only about 3XX responses. About 307 especially.

For clearly, I delete other status codes mentioned in first message. Thanks.

Hmm, I'm not sure I understand what you need or what you are suggesting ğŸ¤” 

Could you please create a minimal self-contained example that shows your use case? â˜•

title: POST response base64
body:
### Example
```Python
class Base64(BaseModel):
    base64_str: str
    photo_name: str

@app.post("/base64")
async def post_base64Image(b64: Base64):
    imgstr = b64.base64_str
    imgdata = base64.b64decode(imgstr)
    filename = '%s.png' % b64.photo_name 
    with open(filename, 'wb') as f:
        f.write(imgdata)
    photo_id = 0
    paths = int(photo_id / 1000) * 1000
    with open(r"E:\images1024x1024\%05d\%05d.png" % (paths, photo_id), "rb") as img_file:
        b64_output = base64.b64encode(img_file.read())
    return {"Image" : b64_output.decode('utf-8')}

    
    
@app.post("/response_model/", response_model=Base64)
async def response_models(b64: Base64):
    photo_id = 0
    paths = int(photo_id / 1000) * 1000
    with open(r"E:\images1024x1024\%05d\%05d.png" % (paths, photo_id), "rb") as img_file:
        b64_output = base64.b64encode(img_file.read())
    b64.base64_str = b64_output.decode('utf-8')
    return b64
```

title: Literal type in get request parameters
body:
```Python
from typing import Literal, Optional

from fastapi import FastAPI


app = FastAPI()


@app.get('/')
def get_test(
    param_int: Optional[Literal[5]] = None,
    param_bool: Optional[Literal[True]] = None,
    param_str: Optional[Literal['a']] = None,
):
    print(param_int, param_bool, param_str)
```

### Description

I expect that I have created params which can be set only to one value. Let's see on Pydantic:
```Python
class A(BaseModel):
    param_str: Optional[Literal['a']] = None
    param_int: Optional[Literal[5]] = None
    param_bool: Optional[Literal[True]] = None
```
`A(param_str='a')` -- expected ok
`A(param_str='b')` -- expected fail
`A(param_int=5)` -- expected ok
`A(param_int=1)` -- expected fail
`A(param_bool=True)` -- expected ok
`A(param_bool=False)` -- expected fail

After let's try to call endpoint
```bash
INFO:     127.0.0.1:53794 - "GET /?param_str=a HTTP/1.1" 200 OK
INFO:     127.0.0.1:53794 - "GET /?param_str=b HTTP/1.1" 422 Unprocessable Entity
INFO:     127.0.0.1:53796 - "GET /?param_int=5 HTTP/1.1" 422 Unprocessable Entity
INFO:     127.0.0.1:53796 - "GET /?param_int=1 HTTP/1.1" 422 Unprocessable Entity
INFO:     127.0.0.1:53798 - "GET /?param_bool=1 HTTP/1.1" 422 Unprocessable Entity
```

So it works only for strings not for int or bool value, doesn't it? How can I use Literal for bool and int?

### Environment

Ubuntu 18.04
Python 3.8.0
fastapi 0.60.1
author: elsimqoz

comments.body: If you use them as strings, it works - `Optional[Literal['True']]` or `Optional[Literal['5']]`
@Mause I got it, but what shall I do if I want to use the original types without conversion? Maybe it is a bug or a feature request?

It's a bug / feature request because pydantic can handle this in e.g. post-requests.

```python
from typing import Literal, Optional
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel

app = FastAPI()

# A Pydantic model
class Item(BaseModel):
    quantity: Literal[5, 10 , 15]

@app.post('/')
def post_test(item: Item
):
    print(item)
```

Here you can just post 5, 10, 15 as int and not a string.

title: Returning an alias of a Field in a response_model
body:
Hi,
i try to return a response_model in which I change the alias to have a different name for the field (one with a dash) in the response .  Settings response_model=TodoBase to this schema:
```python
class TodoBase(BaseModel):
    due_date: Optional[datetime] = Form(None)

    class Config:
        orm_mode = True
```
results in:
```json
{
  "due_date": "2020-11-11T20:15:21.858Z"
}
```
but if try to change it to:
```python
class TodoBase(BaseModel):
    due_date: Optional[datetime] = Form(None, alias="due-date")

    class Config:
        orm_mode = True
```
it results in:
```json
{
  "due_date": null
}

What's wrong? Thanks in advance.
author: emilpaw

comments.body:
what is the body of your post request?
`due_date` or `due-date`?

I fixed my issue by adding `allow_population_by_field_name = True` to the Pydantic model config. Not entirely sure, but I think the problem was that I returned a database model and FastAPI (or Pydantic) could not find "due-date" in it.

That option was very hard to find, maybe it should be mentioned in the documentation. Also the possibility to add an alias to a Pydantic model should be mentioned. Even if it's rather a Pydantic topic, it's pretty useful and not really obvious you can use that.
@emilpaw please close the issue if it has been solved

Thanks for the help here @includeamin ! :clap: :bow:

body:

**When testing (with pytest)**, I want to switch the connected DB to **SQLite3.**

However, when I execute `pytest`, the test fails **because DB has not been switched to SQLite3.**

`conftest.py` as follows:

```python
import pytest
from sqlalchemy import create_engine
from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker
from sqlalchemy_utils import database_exists, drop_database
from src.app.dependencies.database import Base

class User(Base):
     __tablename__ = "User"
     id = Column("id", Integer, primary_key=True, autoincrement=True)
     name = Column("name", String)

@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def SessionLocal():
    # settings of test database
    TEST_SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URL = "sqlite:///./test_temp.db"
    engine = create_engine(
        TEST_SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URL, connect_args={"check_same_thread": False}

    assert not database_exists(
        TEST_SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URL
    ), "Test database already exists. Aborting tests."

    Base.metadata.create_all(engine)
    SessionLocal = sessionmaker(autocommit=False, autoflush=False, bind=engine)

```

`tests/test_user.py` :

```python
def temp_db(f):
    def func(SessionLocal, *args, **kwargs):

        def override_get_db():
            try:
                db = SessionLocal()
                yield db
            finally:
                db.close()

        # cannot override app's dependency...

        # Run tests

client = TestClient(app)

    response = client.get("/api/users")

```python

    except Exception:
        db.close()

app.include_router(
    router, responses={404: {"description": "Not found"}}
)

Test result:

```
tests/test_user.py:21: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
    @temp_db
    def test_fetch_all_users():
        response = client.get("/api/users")
        assert response.status_code == 200
>       assert len(response.json()["data"]) == 0
E       assert 23 == 0
E         +23
E         -0

tests/test_user.py:35: AssertionError
```

title: How to access user credentials send through ajax call with OAuth2PasswordRequestForm
body:
Hi,

I am creating a simple login form on the frontend and sending the username and password to my endpoint with ajax call like this:

**Ajax call to endpoint:**
```
$.ajax({
       type: 'POST',
       url: '/api/token',
       contentType: "application/json",
       dataType: "json",
       data: JSON.stringify( {"username": $("#username").val(), "password": $("#password").val()})
});
```
on the backend I want to receive the credentials and generate a token after successfully login the user like this:

**My endpoint**

```
@app.post("/api/token")
async def login(response: Response, credentials: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(), db: Session = Depends(get_db)):
    user = views.authenticate(db, credentials.username, credentials.password)
    if not user:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="Incorrect username or password")
    access_token = views.gen_token(user.username)
    response.set_cookie(key="access_token", value=f"Bearer {access_token}", httponly=True)
    return
```

with the above code I get error:  `422 Unprocessable Entity` so I replaced  `OAuth2PasswordRequestForm` with my custom pydantic model:

**Login validator:**

```
class LoginValidator(BaseModel):
    username: str
    password: str
```

Now it works but then this line: `response.set_cookie(key="access_token", value=f"Bearer {access_token}", httponly=True)` does not set the cookie and hence the user cannot be logged in. 

**Edit:**

Okay I saw this in docs:

> The spec also states that the username and password must be sent as form data (so, no JSON here).

so I modified ajax call to this:

```
$.ajax({
       type: 'POST',
       url: '/api/token',
       data:{"username": $("#username").val(), "password": $("#password").val()}
});
```

Okay now I don't get error by the cookie is still not set.

title: ValueError: [TypeError("'numpy.float32' object is not iterable",), TypeError('vars() argument must have __dict__ attribute',)]
body: There is "'numpy.float32'   in the return value, How to deal with this
author: yuanjie-ai

comments.body: Return another type instead? Numpy types aren't supported by json

You should simply change the return type.
For example, if you were returning a np.ndarray type object, you can convert it using **tolist()**
EXAMPLE : 
```
import numpy as np

arr = np.array([11, 21, 19])
print(f'NumPy Array: {arr}')
print(type(arr))

list1 = arr.tolist()
print(f'List: {list1}')
print(type(list1))
```
This will remove all the numpy data types from the list.

@Lord-V15 already gave the correct solution but I didn't understand it the first few times reading through it so here's a longer explanation.

This will not work since the return type isn't supported:

```
import numpy as np

@app.get("/")
async def root():
    arr = np.array([11, 21, 19])
    return {"array": arr}
```

This will work as lists are supported:

```
import numpy as np

@app.get("/")
async def root():
    arr = np.array([11, 21, 19])
    return {"array": arr.tolist()}
```

Note that this error will also occur if you are not using `numpy` explicitly but another library that is based on it, such as `pandas`.

title: Mutliple OpenAPI Spec Endpoints on One App
body:
I am working on an application that has quite a large number of endpoints. I have been using tags to group sets of API however the APIs themselves are quite different so I was wondering if there is a way of hosting multiple OpenAPI endoints. 

E.g. 

area1 -> /area1/swagger
area2 -> /area2/swagger
author: cryptoroo

comments.body: thanks for this. Will look later on in the week and let you know how i go

you can create two FastAPI apps and mount them in starlette
```
from fastapi import FastAPI
from starlette.applications import Starlette
from starlette.routing import Mount

api1 = FastAPI(title="API1")
api2 = FastAPI(title="API2")

@api1.get("/test")
def test_api1():
    return "API1"

@api2.get("/test")
def test_api2():
    return "API2"

app = Starlette(routes=[
    Mount("/api1", api1),
    Mount("/api2", api2)
])
```

@ArcLightSlavik -- thanks for looking in to this ğŸ‘ 
@SebastianLuebke thanks for your solution. It worked really well ğŸ‘

Thanks for the help here @SebastianLuebke and @ArcLightSlavik! ğŸ° 

And thanks for coming back to close the issue @cryptoroo â˜• 

> Sorry for the long delay! ğŸ™ˆ  I wanted to personally address each issue/PR and they piled up through time, but now I'm checking each one in order.

title: value_error.jsondecode  Invalid control character at when posting multi line text in FastAPI
body:
hello
this is one of my endpoints which is for posting(creating) new document
```
@app.post("/documents", response_model=Doc, status_code=status.HTTP_201_CREATED, tags=["Web Panel"])
def create_doc(doc: DocDef , token: str = Depends(verified_admin), db: Session = Depends(get_db)):
    pass
    `print("hi")`
```
my schemas are:
```
class DocDef(BaseModel):
    name: str
    doc: str


class Doc(DocDef):
    id: int
    
    class Config:
        orm_mode = True
```
but when I want to test a multi line text document I receive an error 
request body :
```
{
  "name": "string",
  "doc": " this is test.
this is test too."
}
```
response body:
```
{
  "detail": [
    {
      "loc": [
        "body",
        46
      ],
      "msg": "Invalid control character at: line 3 column 25 (char 46)",
      "type": "value_error.jsondecode",
      "ctx": {
        "msg": "Invalid control character at",
        "doc": "{\n  \"name\": \"string\",\n  \"doc\": \" this is test.\nthis is test too.\"\n}",
        "pos": 46,
        "lineno": 3,
        "colno": 25
      }
    }
  ]
}
```


please help how can I fix this 
regards
author: MohashN

comments.body:
Looks very similar to #1982, as @ArcLightSlavik said 

> In JSON a literal line break is not allowed inside a string, it needs to be replaced by \n

So when you want to write a multiline text just go like this

```python
{
  "name": "string",
  "doc": " this is test.\nthis is test too."
}

Thanks for reply
So if I would like to post raw text, Is this only solution?
Yes, JSON doesn't allow breaking lines for readability.
Thanks again

Thanks for the help here @ycd! ğŸ° 

And thanks for coming back to close the issue @MohashN â˜• 

> Sorry for the long delay! ğŸ™ˆ  I wanted to personally address each issue/PR and they piled up through time, but now I'm checking each one in order.
Assuming the original need was handled, this will be automatically closed now. But feel free to add more comments or create new issues or PRs.

title: Automatically adding query parameter to each route in OpenAPI specification
body:
### Example

Here is a small example of my use case, there is a legacy reason why this situation has occurred. Basically we are moving something that used to be a query parameter in all of our routes in a service to being automatically supplied in the header by the reverse proxy in front of the service. All of our routes used to have defined the `team` Query parameter but now this will be no longer used as it will be supplied in the header, I need the middleware to temporarily accept the header and the query parameter as a value as not all services will be updated at once:

```Python
from typing import Optional

from fastapi import FastAPI, APIRouter, Query, HTTPException
from starlette.middleware.base import BaseHTTPMiddleware, RequestResponseEndpoint
from starlette.requests import Request
from starlette.types import ASGIApp
from pydantic import BaseModel
from uvicorn import run

class UserCreds(BaseModel):
    team: Optional[str]

class MyAuthMiddleware(BaseHTTPMiddleware):
    """
    Middleware to inject the attribute `creds` into the request state
    """

    def __init__(self, app: ASGIApp):
        super().__init__(app)

    async def dispatch(self, request: Request, call_next: RequestResponseEndpoint):
        query_param = request.query_params.get("team")
        header=request.headers.get("team")
        if query_param != header:
            raise HTTPException(400, "Query param and header don't align")
        request.state.creds = UserCreds(team=header)
        response = await call_next(request)
        return response


app = FastAPI(title="Test App")
app.add_middleware(MyAuthMiddleware)


router = APIRouter()

@router.get("/items/")
def get_items():
    return "Items"

# I'd like to not go through every route and keep this query parameter so it appears in OpenAPI docs
# Because of the middleware the query parameter is always used
@router.get("/things/")
def get_things(team: Optional[str] = Query(None)):
    return "Things"

app.include_router(router)

run(app)
```

### Description

Essentially what I am trying to do is make it so if a query parameter is used by the middleware then it should insert that query parameter into every route in the OpenAPI specification. I couldn't see anything in the docs that would achieve this. I know that even if I remove the query parameter in the route definition this code will still work but it would be nice if it appeared in the Swagger UI as well.

### Environment

* OS: Linux
* FastAPI Version: 0.61.1
* Python version: 3.8.5
author: ccharlesgb

comments.body: That will work for my use case yes! It would be interesting to be able to add OpenAPI parameters from middleware but that is maybe quite a niche feature.
If you problem is solved, can you please close this issue?

Thanks for the help here everyone! :clap: :bow: 

Thanks for reporting back and closing the issue :+1:

title: Use `>=` instead of `==` for the black requierement in the dev-dependencies
body:
### What?
The title says it all. 

### Why?
I'm using `fastapi[tests]` in my dev-dependencies, and would like to update to newer black versions as soon as they are released. Since fastapi uses `==` for black versions, that's not possible.

### How?
It's very simple: #2249, I also included an update to the current 20.* version since it's been out for a while now, and ran it over `fastapi/`, `pending_tests/`, `scripts/`, and `tests/`.
author: a-recknagel

comments.body:
`fastapi[test]` are meant for tests in the library itself. 
If your making your own tests you need to use `fastapi[all]` which doesn't install black.
Ah, that solves it. Thanks for the info!

Thanks for the help @ArcLightSlavik! ğŸš€ 

And thanks for coming back to close the issue @a-recknagel ğŸ° 

> Sorry for the long delay! ğŸ™ˆ  I wanted to personally address each issue/PR and they piled up through time, but now I'm checking each one in order.
Assuming the original need was handled, this will be automatically closed now. But feel free to add more comments or create new issues or PRs.

title: How to declare Multiple type for request body?
author: jet10000

comments.body:
I did not understand the problem here, but as far as I understand from the title you want to do this.

```python
from fastapi import FastAPI, Body
from typing import Union
from pydantic import BaseModel


class User(BaseModel):
    name: str


class Item(BaseModel):
    size: int
    price: float


app = FastAPI()


@app.post("/multi/")

title: Function currying for Depends over class instances with __call__()
body:
### Description

Function currying is a rather common technique in functional programming. It can also be called local functions, or closures.
A parent function takes an arbitrary number of arguments, and defines a function inside it using those arguments inside its processing. The generated function (closure), can then ask for different arguments to be executed.
In Python, it relies on the parent function having its own scope, and the nested function being able to access it.

This can be used to generate very flexible callable functions, to use as part of Depends().
To create flexible parametrized Depends callable, the documentation only provides examples of a full-blown class instances with requiring both `__init__` and  `__call__` implementations. While most people are probably used to init, `__call__(self)` for a class  is more likely to be a new concept.
I feel like this distracts from more minimal implementations, that don't need OOP everything, especially when this is literally begging for functional style. 
Such complex class + class instance implementation might be granted when it acts on a state it holds and need to mutate as part of its logic, but most cases should be fine with currying.

### Example

```
# generic currying function definition
def currying_filter(key: str, value: str):
    def filter(data: Dict[str: List[str]]):
        data_values = data.get(key, None)
        for item in data_values:
            if item == value:
                return item
        raise HTTPException(status_code=400, detail="No needle found!")
    return filter

# curried function
needle_in_data = currying_filter(key='hay', value='needle')
other_filter = currying_filter(key='book_name', value='Combinatory Logic.')


# which can then be used as such
needle_in_data(data)
```
For a more real-life use case, the nested filter can declare a `Depends()` too, and be depended itself, so endpoints can easily implement various fine-grained checks without needing to implement a more complex class with `__init__` and `__call__` 

```
# like above example but calls a depends. with anything that will return some data.
    def filter(data: dict = Depends(data_source):
        # etc

# then a curried filter can be called in endpoints
@router.post('hay')
async def work_with_needles(needle: str = Depends(needle_in_data):
    # process as usual, with the guaratee that the needle has been filtered upstream.

```
### Other thoughts
While of course, many people are not familiar with functional programming style, or even assume it is possible in Python,
such techniques are already widely spread, and only uses already known common syntax for functions, with the only catch being that it is nested.
It can be introduced as another technique, likely simpler to implement, to generate callables to use as a Depends() callable.

One advantage of using classes instead of curried function is that, being class instances, they have a type associated with it, so one might think that it benefits type hinting. However, the return value of such callables does not have to be the type of the callable itself, so the expectation of typing can actually introduce more confusion. Furthermore, there is no typing inside the call for Depends itself, only for the returned value.

I would like to put some documentation page explaining the technique, or at least some explanation why the technique isn't used, and instead documentation (and internal source code, from I see) makes extensive use of the `__call__()` style, even with no inner data.
author: hhamana

comments.body:

I wouldn't want to add it to the docs and add extra complexity to the concepts explained as that's a technique to generate a function, and not something different from what is already supported. But it's probably worth an independent blog post explaining it.

title: Parallel request getting merged
body:
I  created a API using fastapi. the API accepts a audio file and  text , the audio and text are related to each other and also the text is used till the end of all operations in the API 
```
async def create_file(upload_file:UploadFile = File(...),email: str = Form(...),text:str=Form(...)):
     some operations
     subprocess.popen(cmd)
    stdout, stderr = process.communicate()
```

now when 2 users try to hit the API at the same time the request of 1st user is getting modified and the user 2 response is returned to both the users.
How can i solve this and also the API is on aws with 2 cores linux fedora  os
I am using gunicorn to host it and to run it on two cores 
`gunicorn -w 2 --reload --bind 0.0.0.0:8080 --capture-output  --error-logfile error_log.txt  --access-logfile log.txt -k uvicorn.workers.UvicornWorker main:app
`
_and is it possible to run 2 requests  parallel y on two cores independently  ?_
author: saireddy12

comments.body:
You are experiencing a race condition.
To avoid those easily, you should make sure the file name of the audio file you generate/save is unique, so they do not write to the same file. 
Even better, if you can avoid it, try to work on it in-memory (`from io import ByteIO`) , so you do not have the performance cost from writing to a physical disk.

author: abdalla19977

comments.body:
When you use JWT, Logout have to be implement in front-end and fast-api has nothing to do with it.
Implement your refresh token in an put API.
so is it okay if u logged out u can still use ur token?

Yeah, with the suggested way from @Yeganloo the token would be still valid. if you want to make a real logout you have to create a token blacklist and check in your auth dependency if the token has been revoked.

Thanks for the help @Yeganloo and @SebastianLuebke ! ğŸ° 

Another option is, if you want to allow users to logout every session, part of your user data could include some "seed" (some random data), that is used to hash and verify the token. You would have to get the data for the user from the unverified token, then verify it with the user seed, and then continue if verification passes.

Then to logout every session you could change that user's seed data, that would make any previously emitted token invalid.

title: Merge Path + Query Parameters in BaseModel
body:
Hi all,

I just started using fastapi and I'm struggling to understant how to use the BaseModel on both path + query parameters.

my endpoint:
```
rs = client.get("/data/a/b/c")
# possibly
rs = client.get("/data/a/b/c?sort=true&page=1")
```
On the code below is there a way to make the item return all the optional values declared in the Model?
```python
class Item(BaseModel):
    sort: Optional[str] =  ""
    page: Optional[int] = 1
    per_page: Optional[int] = 20
    search_term: Optional[str] = ""

@app.get("/data/{l1}/{l2}/{l3}")
def d_tree(
           l1: str,
           l2: str,
           l3: str,
           item: Optional[Item] = None):
    print(l1, l2, l3) # l1 l2 l3 ok
    print(item) # None
```

This would throw:
```python
@app.get("/data/{l1}/{l2}/{l3}")
def d_tree(*,
           l1: str,
           l2: str,
           l3: str,
           item: Item):
#{'detail': [{'loc': ['body'], 'msg': 'field required', 'type': 'value_error.missing'}]}
```

I'm wondering if It's possible to get all my variables inside the Model like this:
```python
class Item(BaseModel):
    l1: str
    l2: str
    l3: str
    sort: Optional[str] =  ""
    page: Optional[int] = 1
    per_page: Optional[int] = 20
    search_term: Optional[str] = ""

@app.get("/data/{l1}/{l2}/{l3}")
def d_tree(item: Item):
    toil.phead(item)

    return []
```

### Result
```
{'detail': [{'loc': ['body'], 'msg': 'field required', 'type': 'value_error.missing'}]}
```

### Expect
```
{   
    'l1': 'a',
    'l2': 'b',
    'l3': 'c',
    'page': 1,
    'per_page': 20,
    'search_term': '',
    'sort': ''
}
```
author: CrashLaker

comments.body: Possibly, but it doesn't look like a particularly good design. Query and path parameters typically serve a different purpose. Having both in one model at least violates the Single Responsibility principle.

Hi @jrversteegh,

thank you for your reply.
I understood that indeed isn't a good design.
That said, is it possible to at least return the item object value here with all the default options set?
```python
class Item(BaseModel):
    sort: Optional[str] =  ""
    page: Optional[int] = 1
    per_page: Optional[int] = 20
    search_term: Optional[str] = ""

@app.get("/data/{l1}/{l2}/{l3}")
def d_tree(
           l1: str,
           l2: str,
           l3: str,
           item: Optional[Item] = None):
    print(l1, l2, l3) # l1 l2 l3 ok
    print(item) # None  <---------------- here
```
I was expecting item to be:
```python
item = {
  sort: '',
  page: 1,
  per_page: 20,
  search_term: '',
}
```

I think that doesn't work because Query parameters need to be scalars or a list of scalars. They can't (yet) be objects, but for a flat object like yours, you could do something like:

```python
@dataclass
class Item:
    sort: str =  ""
    page: int = 1
    per_page: int = 20
    search_term: str = ""

@app.get("/data/{l1}/{l2}/{l3}")
def d_tree(
           l1: str,
           l2: str,
           l3: str,
           item: Item = Depends()):
    print(l1, l2, l3) # l1 l2 l3 ok
    print(item) # Should work now
```
Note the `dataclass` decorator, which makes sure that `Item` has an initializer for all its fields.

Hi @jrversteegh,

thank you! it worked :)
Although I'm trying to understand why sort ended up as "True" whereas search_term had the correct value empty string.
```
Item(sort='true', page=1, per_page=20, search_term='')
```
@CrashLaker because you requested `/data/ham/eggs/spam?sort=true` ?

@jrversteegh  err...  yeah nvm
that was dumb.. i'm so sorry. all sorted out now thank you so much :)
np and you're welcome.

title: Django db connection inconsistent between tests and view
body:
Hello,

I just found a workaround to my problem but wanted to see if anyone has had this issue and might have suggestions. I'm using Django purely for its ORM feature with my Postgres DB but FastAPI for everything else. Note I'm not doing anything async. 

Take a simple pytest using django-pytest:
```python
import pytest

from my_django_models import Asset

@pytest.mark.django_db
class TestAssets:
...

    def test_response(self):
        assets = AssetFactory.create_batch(2)
        print(Asset.objects.all())
        resp = self.client.get('/assets')
```
 
The view:
```python
from fastapi import APIRouter

from my_django_models import Asset

router = APIRouter()

@router.get('/assets')
def assets():
    print(Asset.objects.all())
    ...
```

The output:
```
[<Asset: Asset object (1)>, <Asset: Asset object (2)>]
<QuerySet []>
```

So the view has access to the db but it's not actually getting my data for some reason as if it has a bad or incorrect connection.
Now if I inherit from Django's `TransactionTestCase` class and continue using Starlette's TestClient it works... But I don't understand why. So for now that's what I'm doing but wanted to maybe get some clue into why this is the case.

As another note I have made sure I'm pointing at the right settings module and made sure `django.setup()` was called though I think django-pytest does this for me.


Appreciate any info.
author: Subaku

comments.body:
I currently have the same problem. Interestingly, when I debug the app I can see that the connection is still fine when FastAPI validates POST request data, i.e. a query `ModelName.objects.all()` test inside
* test definition âœ… 
* Pydantic model validator method âœ… 
* a view itself âŒ  

However, I performed a little experiment and created a dependency in my view, something like this: 
```python
def get_query():
    return ModelName.objects.all()
```

and if I pass it as a dependency for the view, then it again does not work. âŒ 

Also, I use `pytest` without any classes (i.e. plain `test_` functions)
It seems that the problem can also be mitigated by using `pytest.mark.django_db(transaction=True)` instead of plain `pytest.mark.django_db`

I have the same issue, while migrating all my Django views to FastAPI. The view is working OK at runtime, but I encounter database access issues between pytest and a FastAPI dependency.

```python
test_func.py

"""
pytest fixtures : 
  fastapp (FastAPI initialized app with routers)
  test_client (FastAPI TestClient instance)
  auth (User in DB + API credentials)
"""
def test_func(fastapp, test_client, auth):
    user = User.objects.get(username=auth.username)  # works
    user.check_password(auth.password) # works
    authenticate(username=auth.username, password=auth.password) # works

    response = test_client.get('/', auth=auth) # fails (see comments below)
    ...


router.py

@router.get("/")
def get_foo(user: User = Depends(get_current_user):
    ...


dependencies.py

basic = HTTPBasic()

def get_current_user(credentials: HTTPBasicCredentials = Depends(basic)) -> User:
    # fails (see comments below)
    user = authenticate(username=credentials.username, password=credentials.password)
    ...

```

Test cases :

1. **sqlite in-memory database** : access to ORM (User) ok in the test, fails with `no such table: auth_user` in the FastAPI dependency
2. **sqlite in-memory database + `@pytest.mark.django_db(transaction=True)` annotation on test** : access to ORM (User) ok in the test, fails with `no such table: auth_user` in the FastAPI dependency
2. **sqlite file database** : access to ORM (User) ok in the test, fails with `database table is locked: auth_user` in the FastAPI dependency
3. **sqlite file database + `@pytest.mark.django_db()` annotation on test** : access to ORM (User) ok in the test, fails with `database table is locked: auth_user` in the FastAPI dependency
4. **sqlite file database + `@pytest.mark.django_db(transaction=True)` annotation on test** : access to ORM (User) ok in the test, also OK in the FastAPI dependency

I expected the simplest case (sqlite in-memory database) to work, as it was the case with Django test client. Is there a threading issue there ?

I have the same problem with postgresql. Tests only work using `transactional_db` fixture or `pytest.mark.django_db(transaction=True)` or extending the class `django.test.TransactionTestCase` with my test functions.

It seems that the db is empty in "view" functions even if you create items with the ORM before the call to `client.get` function.

title: Uvicorn workers timeout question
body:
**Some background**
I am not sure if the following details are required to reply to my question but providing them just for reference. I am developing a FastAPI POST endpoint which does the following:

Receives an image file (multipart/form-data)
Converts the file stream to a numpy array.
Processes the image using open CV and tensorflow
The API is deployed on Google App Engine Flex (1-4 cores, 1-4 workers), using gunicorn and uvicorn. When I am calling an endpoint the average response time is ~1 seconds. However, when I am load testing the API with 5 concurrent users the average response time goes to ~4-5 seconds per request and then some uvicorn workers start to timeout and get killed. As a result I receive 502 responses from the nginx server.

**My question is the following:**

Since the default timeout of uvicorn is 30 seconds, I don't undertand why the workers are being terminated before they require ~30 seconds to respond. I have read that the 30 seconds timeout is not per request. However I do not understand under which circumstances a worker is supposed to timeout. For instance, in case all workers manage to respond within 5-10 seconds, is it normal to see workers timeout while the timeout threshold is 30?

> using gunicorn and uvicorn

How are you running gunicorn?

There is a set amount of workers you need to run depending on how many cores there is. (think it's cores * 2 + 1)

I have tried several combinations, including some that are based on this rule. However, I noticed that the larger the number of workers is, the easier it is to reproduce the issue. I am mostly experimenting with 1 core and 2 workers.

title: Long time between request and endpoint code get executed for large List data
body:
### Description

I send image data from my client to FastApi with a request body. I noticed there is a very long time between the moment the request is sent and the moment the code in the end point starts to be executed. 

I don't need to validate input data, so I used "Any" in the base model, but the execution is slow anyway. I don't think it is related to Pydantic (cf. example). 

I joined a reproducible example, with a endpoint that only receives data but does nothing with it.

Does anyone have encountered this problem before? It might be related to the issue #1359, but my problem is on the request side and I didn't manage to extrapolate. 

It might happen also that I am addressing my objective the wrong way, so other implementation suggestions are welcomed.

```Python
from typing import List, Any
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel
import numpy as np
import datetime
import time


class PredictRequest(BaseModel):
    #images: List[List[List[int]]]  # Even slower, overhead seems to be on the pydantic side in that case
    images: Any


app = FastAPI()

@app.post("/DummyEndPoint")
def predict(input: PredictRequest):
    print("Time data available in endpoint: ", datetime.datetime.utcnow())
    return



def run_pydantic_validation(data):
    print("PYDANTIC:")
    ts = time.time()
    validated_data = dict(PredictRequest(**data))
    print("Pydantic validation time: ", time.time() - ts)

def run_endpoint(data):
    from starlette.testclient import TestClient
    from starlette.status import HTTP_200_OK

    test_client = TestClient(app)

    ts = time.time()
    print("FASTAPI:")
    print("Time the data is sent: ", datetime.datetime.utcnow())
    response = test_client.post("/DummyEndPoint", json=data)
    assert response.status_code == HTTP_200_OK
    print("Time to run the dummy endpoint: ", time.time() - ts)


images = np.zeros((1000, 256, 256))  # Simulate 1000 images of size 256*256 (grayscale, so there is no color axis)
data = {'images': images.tolist()}

run_pydantic_validation(data=data)
run_endpoint(data=data)
```


### Environment

* OS: Linux 
* FastAPI Version: 0.61.1
* Python version: 3.7

comments.body:
Are you sure the images you make from numpy are correct? Running `print(images.tolist())` seemingly prints a bunch of '0' without end. 

Besides that doing `images = [[[1000, 256, 256]]]` results in good time
```
Time the data is sent: 2020-09-18 11:56:53.287025
Time data available in endpoint: 2020-09-18 11:56:53.309983
Time to run the dummy endpoint: 0.023695945739746094
```

Thanks for your reply. 
My images from numpy are correct. I did not mentioned it clearly, but here images represents a batch of 1000 images, each being 256*256 pixels. So in the minimal example above it is a bunch of zeros, but in the real project, it is meaningful pixel values to be processed further.

@ArcLightSlavik 
Even with setting `images = [[[1000, 256, 256]]]`  does not help, at least when I test it locally, I think the results are based on the system spec also, I am getting around 22 secs on my local machine and around 3secs on my VM

I made my example even more simpler, independent from Pydantic and encoding the image data as bytes. 

```Python 
from fastapi import FastAPI, File
import numpy as np
import datetime
import time
import base64

app = FastAPI()

@app.post("/DummyEndPoint")
def predict(images: bytes = File(...)):
    print("Time data available in endpoint: ", datetime.datetime.utcnow())
    return


def run_endpoint(data):
    from starlette.testclient import TestClient
    from starlette.status import HTTP_200_OK

    test_client = TestClient(app)

    ts = time.time()
    print("FASTAPI:")
    print("Time the data is sent: ", datetime.datetime.utcnow())
    response = test_client.post("/DummyEndPoint", files=data)
    assert response.status_code == HTTP_200_OK
    print("Time to run the dummy endpoint: ", time.time() - ts)


images = np.zeros((1000, 256, 256))  # Simulate 1000 images of size 256*256 (grayscale, so there is no color axis)
data = {'images': base64.b64encode(images)}

run_endpoint(data=data)
```

The time to enter the endpoint went down on my machine from 13.5 to 2.7 sec. This time is now more reasonable with regard to the processing time in my projects endpoint. 

However I am not sure what improved here, if it is because I got rid of pydantic and/or because I converted the data to bytes (size of the data sent is almost similar, around 600MB).

I'm experiencing something similar, with the TestClient, connecting to a running instance using curl or insomnia is fast enough, but the tests are taking too much, I'm using python 3.8 under pipenv, no changes on the versions of fastapi nor python under the virtualenv, one thing that happened was a change in some policies and antivirus on my Mac, will do some more testing tomorrow.

title: Dependency Overrides in startup event gives TypeError: 'Depends' object is not callable
body:
How can dependencies in the startup event be overwritten for testing?

Below a minimal example. When executing the test, `Model` is a `Depends` object and not a `MagicMock`. When putting the depends in normal endpoints it works just fine.

api.py
```python 
from my_package.model import Model
from fastapi import Depends, FastAPI
app = FastAPI()

def model_provider():
    return Model

model = None

@app.on_event("startup")
def startup(Model = Depends(model_provider)):
    global model
    model = Model()

@app.get("/prediction")
def predict(x):
    return model.predict(x)

```

tests/test_api.py
````python
from my_package import api
from unittest.mock import MagicMock
from fastapi.testclient import TestClient

def test_predict():
    model_mock = MagicMock()
    model_mock.predict = MagicMock(return_value=lambda x: x)
    api.app.dependency_overrides[api.model_provider] = lambda: model_mock
    with TestClient(api.app) as client:
        prediction = client.get("/prediction?x=1")
        assert prediction.text == "1"

```
author: timbmg

comments.body: The documents seems to hint that you can only use `Depends` for request functions. Perhaps this could be extended to app events as well?
+1 this would be great to use dependencies in event handlers. Now it is Starlette events which know nothing about FastAPI DI

+1, the DI is a very important design feature of FastAPI that should be usable in event handler IMO.

Unless already planned for future release, I would like to contribute to this, but this doesn't seems that easy to implement it in a clean way. By reading DI implementation currently used, I realize that it is deeply connected to request / response game, with no separation of concern allowing to just refactor `fastapi.dependencies.utils.solve_dependencies` function to handle an event only use case.

A quick intuition is that it should have a more granular `Dependent` / `Depends` hierarchy like having a base `Dependent` definition without any `Body`, `Form`, `Request`, `Response`, etc ... support and adding those to a child `RequestDependent` before to finally break solver function to support either both use case or smartly trigger errors when unsupported request deps are required in an "non request" context.

But maybe there is a simpler way ?
@Faylixe I took a look, and I agree with your assessment. It looks doable without breaking changes, but yeah a _lot_ of refactoring would be needed.

title: How can I change 'Bearer' prefix in OAuth2PasswordBearer
body: I'm using OAuth2PasswordBearer scheme, the rest of my services has authorisation prefix 'JWT' instead of 'Bearer', how can I change it?
author: DireWereWolf

comments.body:
instead of using `OAuth2PasswordBearer` directly.
create a custom class that inherit from it and override `__call__` method and change `bearer` to `jwt`.
```
class OAuth2PasswordJWT(OAuth2PasswordBearer):
    def __init__(
        self,
        tokenUrl: str,
        scheme_name: Optional[str] = None,
        scopes: Optional[dict] = None,
        auto_error: bool = True,
    ):
        super().__init__(
            tokenUrl=tokenUrl,
            scopes=scopes,
            scheme_name=scheme_name,
            auto_error=auto_error,
        )

    async def __call__(self, request: Request) -> Optional[str]:
        authorization: str = request.headers.get("Authorization")
        scheme, param = get_authorization_scheme_param(authorization)
        if not authorization or scheme.lower() != "jwt":
            if self.auto_error:
                raise HTTPException(
                    status_code=status.HTTP_401_UNAUTHORIZED,
                    detail="Not authenticated",
                    headers={"WWW-Authenticate": "JWT"},
                )
            else:
                return None
        return param
```
Thanks a lot

Thanks for the help here @Bezmehrabi ! :clap: :bow: 

Thanks for reporting back and closing the issue @DireWereWolf  :+1:

Have in mind that "Bearer" is just the format for a token sent in the header, which is integrated with OAuth2, JWT as a prefix is probably not part of any standard and would probably not have as much compatibility as "Bearer". Also, "Bearer" doesn't imply anything about the token, so it would most commonly be JWT, and it could be something else as well.

title: Wrong route in FastAPi
body:
Hello I would like to know how to override the function that manages non-existing route, I can't find anything on the internet or I don't understand at all how to do it because I've tried everything I think.

If someone can help me to change the message 
{
    "detail": "Not Found"
}

when you try to contact the server with a bad route or / and method

Thank you very much.
Best regards,
author: Misteur54

comments.body:
Exactly, you can override the default HTTPException with Starlette's HTTPException

```python
from fastapi import FastAPI, Request
from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse
from starlette.exceptions import HTTPException as StarletteHTTPException


@app.exception_handler(StarletteHTTPException)
async def http_exception_handler(request: Request, exc: StarletteHTTPException):
    return JSONResponse({"message":"endpoint not found" })
```

Now when i send a request to undefined endpoint, i 'll see this

```python
INFO:     127.0.0.1:48818 - "GET /not_defined_endpoint HTTP/1.1" 200 OK
Out:        "message":"endpoint not found"
```

If you want to include the default details you can do this:

```python
from fastapi import FastAPI, Request
from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse
from starlette.exceptions import HTTPException as StarletteHTTPException
from fastapi.encoders import jsonable_encoder

@app.exception_handler(StarletteHTTPException)
async def http_exception_handler(request: Request, exc: StarletteHTTPException):
    return JSONResponse({"detail:":jsonable_encoder(exc), "message":"endpoint not found" })
```
Now you can see the default exceptions are included too.
```python
INFO:     127.0.0.1:48844 - "GET /not_defined_endpoint HTTP/1.1" 200 OK
,Out:       {"detail:":{"status_code":404,"detail":"Not Found"},"message":"endpoint not found"}
```

@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_get_topic_list_service():
    service = Service()
    result = await service.get_topic_list(page=1, per=1)
```

I think dependency injection through `Depends()` does not support on pytest, or other approach.

So maybe I have to mocking Depends(), but I don't know exactly how can I do.

Any best way for this case?

### Environment

* OS: macOS
* FastAPI Version: 0.61.0
* Python version: 3.8.2

### Additional context

<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the question here. -->
author: teamhide

comments.body: Are you using cbv from fastapi_utils?

You can't instantiate `Service()` directly. It's meant to be a dependency (it has a dependency on its constructor). If you want to check exactly what is happening:
```python
from apps.topic.services import Service
import pytest


@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_get_topic_list_service():
    service = Service()
    print(service.topic_repo) # Here!
    result = await service.get_topic_list(page=1, per=1)
```

What I recommend is that you mock the `Service()` attribute `topic_repo`. Something like:
```
mocker.patch(service, 'topic_repo', <value>) 
```

@ycd Nope.
@Kludex with `pytest-mock` library?
@teamhide yes
I have the same problem, but in my case, is occurring when I use Depends i another function thats aren't from path operations.

If you have a class that is expected to be used as a dependency with subdependencies and you need to use it directly in other places in the code, you need to pass the keyword argument for the subdependencies manually.

So, you need to call it as normal Python code. In that case, FastAPI has nothing to do with it.

uvicorn main:app --port 8080 --timeout-keep-alive 500

title: Question: use Fast API Dependency Injection separately from the API routes.
body:
I have a complicated business logic that dependent on other services (6+ services). 
I would like to test part of the business logic service without running FastAPI TestClient while i need to test only part of it, and not full API call.

Is it possible to reuse build in Dependency Injection  in the Fast API in order to resolve dependent services? 

Example: 
```
class ComputationService:
    def calc():
        # some computations
        return 0
    def transform(i):
        return i+1

class BLService:
    __init__(service:ComputationService = Depends(ComputationService)):
        self.service = service

    def calc_and_transform(self):
        result = self.service.calc()
        transformed = self.service.transform(result)
        return transformed

def unit_test():

       result = blService.calc_and_transform()
       # expected is result 1 
```

Also, is it designed for such use-cases or it's better to use another dependency injection library in parallel?

author: ievgennaida

comments.body:
I was actually just about to open a similar issue.  It would be pretty incredible if the devs could actually pull the dependency injection concept out of fastAPI and into a standalone library.  I'm genuinely not smart enough to figure out if that's actually possible, but if so it would be a godsend.

An additional reason for this:

Ideally, in support of long-term best-practices, my service logic should be a library that can be wrapped by _any_ API framework (or maybe it just lives in a lambda?  Or a script?  Why should it be coupled to HTTP at all?)

It makes a ton of sense to say that I should essentially have a standalone library for "doing something" and then a FastAPI wrapper around the inputs and outputs of that library to HTTP-ify them.  But doing so today is nearly impossible because I find the `Depends` structure really valuable for dependency resolution, and I use it all the way down the stack for a variety of useful reasons.

Have anyone else gave this a thought?

This seems as a serious limitation of FastAPI's dependency injection, in terms of scalability. Passing dependency reference from the route method to all other services kinda defeats the purpose of DI.

I think decoupling the FastAPI DI from the request pipeline would really help in a number of scenarios, however I am not sure if this is even a priority or concern for the guys at FastAPI

I'm gonna post a dirty hack that helped me tap into the DI without having it come from a FastAPI request

```python
from contextlib import AsyncExitStack
from typing import Any
from typing import AsyncGenerator
from typing import Callable
from typing import Coroutine
from typing import Optional

from fastapi.dependencies.utils import get_dependant
from fastapi.dependencies.utils import solve_dependencies
from starlette.requests import Request
from main import app


async def resolve(callable_dep: Callable) -> Any:
    dependent = get_dependant(path="", call=callable_dep)
    values, _, _, _, _ = await solve_dependencies(
        request=__mock_request(),
        dependant=dependent,
        dependency_overrides_provider=app
    )
    resolved = await __create_instance(callable_dep, **values)

    if not resolved:
        raise Exception("failed to create dependency")

    return resolved


def __mock_request() -> Request:
    astack = AsyncExitStack()
    app_instance = {"app": app, "fastapi_astack": astack}
    scope = {"type": "http", "method": "GET", "headers": "", "cookies": "", "query_string": ""}
    return Request({**app_instance, **scope})


async def __create_instance(callable_dep: Callable, **kwargs) -> Optional[Any]:
    instance = callable_dep(**kwargs)
    if isinstance(instance, AsyncGenerator):
        resolved: Optional[Any] = next(iter([i async for i in instance]), None)
    elif isinstance(instance, Coroutine):
        resolved = await instance
    else:
        resolved = instance
    return resolved

```

this is not ideal but it works for anyone who wants to take this and actually do something with it while they figure out a better way to manage their deps

In the example function of the official website, the user logs in to create a tokenï¼š

```
def create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: Optional[timedelta] = None):
    to_encode = data.copy()
    if expires_delta:
        expire = datetime.utcnow() + expires_delta  # ------------------------------------------- this line
    else:
        expire = datetime.utcnow() + timedelta(minutes=15)  # ------------------------------------------- this line
    to_encode.update({"exp": expire})
    encoded_jwt = jwt.encode(to_encode, SECRET_KEY, algorithm=ALGORITHM)
    return encoded_jwt
```


In the validation functionï¼š

```
async def get_current_user(token: str = Depends(oauth2_scheme)):
    credentials_exception = HTTPException(
        status_code=status.HTTP_401_UNAUTHORIZED,
        detail="Could not validate credentials",
        headers={"WWW-Authenticate": "Bearer"},
    )
    try:
        payload = jwt.decode(token, SECRET_KEY, algorithms=[ALGORITHM])   # No matter how to verify, it can be verified correctly,
        username: str = payload.get("sub")
        if username is None:
            raise credentials_exception
        token_data = TokenData(username=username)
    except JWTError:
        raise credentials_exception
    user = get_user(fake_users_db, username=token_data.username)
    if user is None:
        raise credentials_exception
    return user
```

No matter how to verify, it can be verified correctly, and the set failure time has no effect. But when I change the expiration time toï¼š

>  **expire = time.time() + 900  # 900 is seconds**

it works!

I don't know if it's a problem, if it's OK. Just ignore it.
author: zizle

comments.body: @zizle were you having problems with it? Was it not working as expected?

> @zizle were you having problems with it? Was it not working as expected?

In login logic, create a user token: expire = datetime.utcnow() + timedelta(minutes=15) It never expired.
but,this way: expire = time.time() + 900 # seconds=900 It correctlyã€‚

I don't know if it's a problem, if it's OK. Just ignore it.

title: How to define and use global exceptionsï¼Ÿ
body:
```Python
import uvicorn
from fastapi import FastAPI
from flask import Request
from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse
from Api.api import api_router


class UnicornException(Exception):
    def __init__(self, name: str):
        self.name = name


app = FastAPI()


@app.exception_handler(UnicornException)
async def unicorn_exception_handler(request: Request, exc: UnicornException):
    return JSONResponse(
        status_code=418,
        content={"message": f"Oops! {exc.name} did something. There goes a rainbow..."},
    )


app.include_router(api_router, prefix="/api/v1")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    uvicorn.run("Start:app", host="0.0.0.0", port=8080, log_level="info")

```
```python3
from fastapi import APIRouter

from Api import webApi

api_router = APIRouter()
api_router.include_router(webApi.router, tags=["webApi"])

```
```python3
from fastapi import APIRouter

from Start import UnicornException
from WebInit import test
from allmain.StartInit import stop_all_containers, get_ssh_public_key, request_yml_data
from bean.YmalBean import Yml

router = APIRouter()


@router.get("/1")
def read_root():
    # StartInit.get_ssh_public_key()
    raise UnicornException(name="asdasd")
```
```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/k/PycharmProjects/auto/Start.py", line 5, in <module>
    from Api.api import api_router
  File "/home/k/PycharmProjects/auto/Api/api.py", line 3, in <module>
    from Api import webApi
  File "/home/k/PycharmProjects/auto/Api/webApi.py", line 3, in <module>
    from Start import UnicornException
  File "/home/k/PycharmProjects/auto/Start.py", line 5, in <module>
    from Api.api import api_router
ImportError: cannot import name 'api_router'

```
author: lnsane

comments.body:
You're having a __Circular Import__ problem. I suggest you do this.

__Start.py__ - under root folder
```py
import uvicorn
from fastapi import FastAPI
from flask import Request
from fastapi.responses import JSONResponse
from Api.api import api_router
from exceptions import main # or from exceptions.main import UnicornException

app = FastAPI()

@app.exception_handler(main.UnicornException)
async def unicorn_exception_handler(request: Request, exc: main.UnicornException):
    return JSONResponse(
        status_code=418,
        content={
            "message": f"Oops! {exc.name} did something. There goes a rainbow..."},
    )


app.include_router(api_router, prefix="/api/v1")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    uvicorn.run("Start:app", host="0.0.0.0", port=8080, log_level="info")
```

__Api/api.py__
```py
from fastapi import APIRouter

from Api import webApi

api_router = APIRouter()
api_router.include_router(webApi.router, tags=["webApi"])
```

__Api/webApi.py__
```py
from fastapi import APIRouter
from exceptions import main # or from exceptions.main import UnicornException

router = APIRouter()

@router.get("/1")
def read_root():
    raise main.UnicornException(name="Error")
```

__exceptions/main.py__
```py

class UnicornException(Exception):
    def __init__(self, name: str):
        self.name = name


class AnotherException(Exception):
    def __init__(self, message: str, status: int):
        self.message = message
        self.status = status
```

title: mutipart/form-data not working on TestClient
body:
```python
from fastapi import APIRouter, File, Form, UploadFile

router = APIRouter()

@router.post("/upload", response_model=MyResponseModel, summary="user csv upload api")
async def upload(
    user_id: int = Form(..., example=1),
    csv_file: UploadFile = File(...),
):
    """
    some code...
    """
```

I checked on swagger(/docs). It was successful.


but, failed in test code

```python
from myapp import app

class UploadTest(unittest.TestCase):
    client = TestClient(app)

    def test_upload(self):
        with csv.open("rb") as f:
            filebody = f.read()
        res = self.client.post(
            "/api/upload",
            data={
                "user_id": 1
            },
            files={
                "csv_file": ("filename.csv", filebody),
            },
            headers={"Content-Type": "multipart/form-data"})
        self.assertEqual(status.HTTP_200_OK, res.status_code)
        MyResponseModel.parse_obj(res.json()["data"])
```

```
Error getting request body: can't concat NoneType to bytes
{'detail': 'There was an error parsing the body'}
```
author: cln-m4rie

comments.body:
It's not an issue related to FastAPI. 

Requests sets the content-type header automatically if you use files. 

Thus, delete: `headers={"Content-Type": "multipart/form-data"}`

Otherwise, you may have to deal with boundary (`Content-Type: multipart/form-data;boundary="boundary"`) which is not what you want :)

Thanks for the help here @marodev ! :clap: :bow: 

Thanks for reporting back and closing the issue @cln-m4rie  :+1:

title: ResponseModel does not force model
author: datenwort

comments.body:
You should not return a `JSONResponse` instance if you want FastAPI to handle your models. 
Remember that `get` is a decorator which already uses `JSONResponse` (to be honest is not a `JSONResponse` but is a parent or child class if I remember correctly). How we handle it in FastAPI:
```
class Item(BaseModel):
    id: int
    shortcut: str
    name: str

@app.get("/items/{item_id}", response_model=Item)
async def get_all_items(item_id: int):
    """Return all assocations."""
    item = {"name": "name", "size": "size"}
    return item
```
But this will raise an error. Can you see why? 

**SPOILER ALERT!!!**
Because you have the field `shortcut` and `id` are required ones!!! How do we solve it? There are several ways, I'll show you the simplest for me:
```
class Item(BaseModel):
    id: Optional[int]
    shortcut: Optional[str]
    name: str

@app.get("/items/{item_id}", response_model=Item)
async def get_all_items(item_id: int):
    """Return all assocations."""
    item = {"name": "name", "size": "size"}
    return item
```

As I mentioned, I was expecting the error. Thanks for clarify how to return it.
Will add the status code with the response object instead.

Thanks for the help here @Kludex ! :clap: :bow: 

Thanks for reporting back and closing the issue @datenwort  :+1:

title: When Depends is not evaluated
body:
Hi folks.

I think I'm missing something profound with Dependency injection concept in FastAPI.

Let's take this example: I have a function that is called somewhere inside the call chain of processing request and it has dependency. This is NOT the top-level api function which is usually marked by decorator like this `@router.get('/some_path')`

```
def some_callable_here():
     ...
     return some_value

async def do_something(some_var: str = Depends(some_callable_here)):
     # do something
```
My understanding of what happens here: if you don't pass value for `some_var` when calling `do_something`, this value gets injected using `Depends` by calling `some_callable_here`. 

My question: what do you absolutely need for this `Depends` to be evaluated? What I get in my is that `some_var` has value `Depends(...)` inside `do_something` which means that `some_callable_here` has never been evaluated. This question seems very abstract, but I'm lost and I don't know how to approach this problem. Maybe I can get to the answer myself if you point me to the part of code where `Depends` gets evaluated.

Thank you!
author: swsvc

comments.body: Nevermind. In my case dependency injection won't work indeed. Hint for people who will struggle with the same problem: don't mix business logic with framework entities
Thanks for reporting back and closing the issue :+1:
